Dispute_Type: Liability and limitation of liability in maritime collision
Legal_Issue: Whether Sheena M Interests can obtain a stay of the liability action while pursuing a limitation action
Governing_Law: 1976 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims
Section 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Potential prejudice to Sheena M Interests from concurrent actions
Lack of significant harm to CPR if stay is granted
Decision_Outcome: Stay granted for liability action against all defendants except Rivtow Marine Ltd.
Burden_of_Proof: On Sheena M Interests to demonstrate that a stay is in the interests of justice
Legal_Rule: Shipowners may limit liability under the 1976 Convention unless intentional or reckless fault is proven; courts may grant stays under Section 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act if in the interests of justice
Grounds_for_Claim: Collision between tugboat Sheena M and CPR bridge resulting in damage
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; procedural stay granted
Key_Evidence_Considered: Risk of prejudice to Sheena M Interests
Legal_Framework: 1976 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims
Defendant_Response: CPR opposed the stay, arguing against disruption of the liability action
Evidence_Type: Legal argument on jurisdiction and procedure
Remedy_Requested: Stay of liability action pending resolution of limitation action
Outcome: Stay granted; liability action paused until limitation action is resolved

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to persecution by Jamaat-e-Islami in Bangladesh
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with procedural timelines for appeal
Misrepresentation_Element: Adverse credibility findings on key claims including Telephone Threats and Family Threat
Procedural_Issue: RAD partially overturned RPD's credibility findings but upheld overall decision
Evidence_Used: Police corruption evidence, statements on threats from Jamaat-e-Islami
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient corroboration for threat claims, inconsistencies in testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility assessment on multiple grounds; Non-Reporting finding overturned due to police corruption
Decision_Outcome: RPD dismissed appeal, RAD confirmed dismissal
Relief_Sought: Allowance of refugee appeal, reversal of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Other negative credibility findings sufficient to support dismissal despite overturning one finding
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'Goût de Beurre Comme au Cinéma' is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Consumer surveys deemed unreliable as they focused on packaging, not the trademark itself
Burden_of_Proof: On opponent (Dairy Farmers of Canada) to show non-registrability
Credibility_Factor: Survey evidence considered insufficient due to focus on packaging
Legal_Rule: Trademarks must not be clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of goods
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on alleged descriptiveness and deceptive misdescription
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark not found to be clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive when considered in its entirety
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of the mark as a whole, including 'comme au cinéma'
Defendant_Response: Hunt-Wesson defended the registrability of the mark
Outcome: Registrar's decision upheld; costs awarded to respondent
Legal_Provision: s. 38(2), s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar's decision to maintain the OX & PALM trademark registration was reasonable under section 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from the Registrar's decision to the Federal Court; judicial review
Evidence_Assessment: Heinz registered the trademark and sold products to a Canadian distributor within the relevant period; delivery occurred slightly after the period
Decision_Outcome: Registrar's decision upheld; trademark not expunged
Burden_of_Proof: On party challenging the registration to show non-use or invalidity
Credibility_Factor: Registrar found Heinz's evidence of use sufficient despite timing discrepancy
Legal_Rule: Section 45 requires evidence of use in Canada during a three-year period or justification for non-use due to special circumstances
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged non-use of the OX & PALM trademark in Canada during the statutory period
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim to expunge trademark failed; Heinz retains registration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales to Canadian distributor within the relevant period, even if delivery was slightly delayed
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, section 45 – maintenance of registration based on use
Defendant_Response: Heinz demonstrated use through sales to Canadian distributor and justified timeline
Remedy_Requested: Expungement of the OX & PALM trademark registration
Outcome: Application to expunge denied; trademark registration maintained
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Ms. Kerzner met the criteria under subsection 129.2(4) to extend the time for requesting a Minister's decision
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time to request a Minister's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: The court found that Mr. Kerzner received the Seizure Receipt and acted on Ms. Kerzner's behalf, establishing constructive notice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate inability to act or bona fide intention within the 90-day period
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claim of non-receipt of notice undermined by evidence of husband’s receipt and agency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension under section 129.2 requires (a) application within one year after expiration of original period and (b) demonstration of inability to act or bona fide intention within original 90 days
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of equitable considerations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Missed 90-day deadline due to alleged lack of notice and late realization of intent
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application failed on merits due to lack of timely intention or inability to act
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Seizure Receipt received by husband, actions taken on behalf of Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed no notice of seizure within 90 days; intention formed only in December 2004
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (Seizure Receipt), agency relationship
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to request a Minister's decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Ms. Kerzner met the criteria under subsection 129.2(4) to extend the time for requesting a Minister's decision
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time to request a Minister's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court found no evidence of inability to act or timely bona fide intention; husband’s receipt of notice attributed to Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to meet all three criteria under subsection 129.2(4)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible explanation for delay; awareness inferred through spouse's actions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: To obtain extension: (i) inability or bona fide intent within 90 days, (ii) just and equitable, (iii) application made as soon as circumstances permitted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged ignorance of seizure due to lack of direct notice
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed for failure to satisfy statutory conditions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Seizure Receipt delivered to husband, no timely action by Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Asserted lack of knowledge of seizure and need for extension due to delayed awareness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, spousal agency
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to challenge seizure decision
